text:
hmmmm....well I would counter, trading could be fundamentally different as when betting we're looking for outright value, i.e. fair value of runner x is 4, therefore back @ 5, or runners y & z have a combined probability of 0.25 so back if combined probability is available @ .2 (and so on).

When trading people could be looking at value purely vs the last 2 mins or 5 mins or whatever, but that doesn't mean the trade makes sense at the point of going in play as the runner isn't 'cheap', the trader is merely taking a very short term view the price will shorten and they will get a chance to get out, hence the need to close out (arguably).

text: <@U4H19D1D2> absolutely...but 'value's is subjective, my point was that the value we tend to talk about is simply is basically if runner x == cheap place back bet...but value for a trader could mean the runner in this 30 second period is better than the last 30 seconds, if that runner then becomes expensive you close the trade, which is fundamentally the same logic as laying outright if a runner is to expensive. Its just over a shorter time frame.

text: <@UFTBRB3F1> Sounds like you are talking about probability of a market moving in a certain direction, as opposed to the probability of the selection you are placing bets on winning or not. If you believe in things like CLV then you would expect your price to converge to what is "correct" in which case your short term move is likely to be caused by whether the current price is "value" - regardless of it being a back or a lay entry.

elements.text: Sounds like you are talking about probability of a market moving in a certain direction, as opposed to the probability of the selection you are placing bets on winning or not. text: <@U4H19D1D2> that makes complete sense...but I would argue that's not necessarily the same thing as trading still. Hedging value bets doesn't make sense. But you can trade non-value bets for profit if you can identify movements. For example if you have a series of indicators that suggest runner x will shorten, even though it offers no outright value, you may be able to trade in and out of that, yet you'd never outright back it. That said...to disprove myself to some degree, I guess you would then argue, why bother backing in the first place, just wait and lay it!

text:
My £0.02 before the brawl kicks off...
Personally, I "value" bet based around what I perceive as the "true" price. Sometimes I inadvertently end up with a hedge purely because I have achieved value on both sides of the market. For me, trading/hedging is about locking in a profit because you're not certain whether or not you actually have any value at all. Both bets could be placed at poor value and you would be simply trading the spread/commission/fluctuations. I don't intentionally hedge my bets, as I value bet and therefore don't see the point in giving away ££.

elements.text:
My £0.02 before the brawl kicks off...
Personally, I "value" bet based around what I perceive as the "true" price. Sometimes I inadvertently end up with a hedge purely because I have achieved value on both sides of the market. For me, trading/hedging is about locking in a profit because you're not certain whether or not you actually have any value at all. Both bets could be placed at poor value and you would be simply trading the spread/commission/fluctuations. I don't intentionally hedge my bets, as I value bet and therefore don't see the point in giving away ££.

attachments.text:
My thoughts on this, and the more I developed my personal hedging I am thinking it is going be very hard to achieve something that is going to suits a general requirements. Weak markets / bad positions with a generalised hedge function, will only lead to frustration and asking for a more specific hedging.

Stop loss assumes volume is available which is another big issue and again people will complain probably when they get hit for more then the stop loss.

If there was going to be a hedging function I would keep it simple and just allow for it to be called X seconds to off, to fully green up and spread the profit across all selections. It should be done on the trade level for sure to keep things simple again.

Id say that if was going to be done properly then it would require some form of larger hedging class, but again after a few weeks of thought I now am in the camp of leave it to the user unless the function is simple and quite restrictive in nature.
attachments.title: Comment on #267 Add hedging/take-profit/stop loss functionality

text:
In my personal (using BFLW, not Flumine) code, I have code that does automatic offsets.

So I try to enter with a fill or kill. If that gets filled, it places the offset order. This is a limit. Not a stop. I don't use stops. I scale my bets such that I am willing to ride out any potential loss on an individual trades.

However, if I did not use a fill or kill, the logic could be complicated. As what should the code do if there is only a partial fill? What if it is partially filled, and the appropriate hedge size is not a valid bet size?

What if it is partially filled in really small clips? A bot that hedged every small clip could run afoul of transaction limits/costs.

What if the user wants to cancel the original, partially filled trade, and the hedging state is left in a mess due to reasons stated above?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text:
In my personal (using BFLW, not Flumine) code, I have code that does automatic offsets.

So I try to enter with a fill or kill. If that gets filled, it places the offset order. This is a limit. Not a stop. I don't use stops. I scale my bets such that I am willing to ride out any potential loss on an individual trades.

However, if I did not use a fill or kill, the logic could be complicated. As what should the code do if there is only a partial fill? What if it is partially filled, and the appropriate hedge size is not a valid bet size?

What if it is partially filled in really small clips? A bot that hedged every small clip could run afoul of transaction limits/costs.

What if the user wants to cancel the original, partially filled trade, and the hedging state is left in a mess due to reasons stated above?

text:
It's nothing groundbreaking or different to what the guys are saying here really, but sure
```A strategy only has positive expected value if each bet that you take is a value bet (e.g. you think there's an 80% chance of something happening, market thinks there's only a 50% chance, so you back it).

Assuming your opening trades *do* take value then you should not trade out of it _unless_ your closing trade is ALSO a value trade. If you close 100% of your opening trades by default without considering value then your closing trades are going to have negative value over time (due to fees and spread), and you'll lose money through them.

Ideally, forget the idea of "closing" a trade. Just run two strategies independently, a backing strategy and laying strategy. Ensure each of them only takes a position when there's value, and that'll make sure they have positive EV in long term. Sure, there'll be cases when you back something cus you think there's value, and 10 mins lay it because you think there's value given new stuff that's happened in the game. It looks like you closed your original back, but really you just took two value bets.

Unless you take the same approach with scalping, you're just taking an uneducated guess and over time will lose money. To apply the same principle to scalping, you ought to think: my prediction of no goal over next 5 mins is X% and the market says Y%. If X% > Y% then open your scalping position as this is value. Then when the 5 mins is over, revaluate your forecast. If X% > Y% then there's no reason to close your scalp. If X% < Y%, then you will close your scalp with a value bet.


Of course this assumes that your detection of value is actually somewhat sensible.```

elements.text: It's nothing groundbreaking or different to what the guys are saying here really, but sure

A strategy only has positive expected value if each bet that you take is a value bet (e.g. you think there's an 80% chance of something happening, market thinks there's only a 50% chance, so you back it).

Assuming your opening trades *do* take value then you should not trade out of it _unless_ your closing trade is ALSO a value trade. If you close 100% of your opening trades by default without considering value then your closing trades are going to have negative value over time (due to fees and spread), and you'll lose money through them.

Ideally, forget the idea of "closing" a trade. Just run two strategies independently, a backing strategy and laying strategy. Ensure each of them only takes a position when there's value, and that'll make sure they have positive EV in long term. Sure, there'll be cases when you back something cus you think there's value, and 10 mins lay it because you think there's value given new stuff that's happened in the game. It looks like you closed your original back, but really you just took two value bets.

Unless you take the same approach with scalping, you're just taking an uneducated guess and over time will lose money. To apply the same principle to scalping, you ought to think: my prediction of no goal over next 5 mins is X% and the market says Y%. If X% > Y% then open your scalping position as this is value. Then when the 5 mins is over, revaluate your forecast. If X% > Y% then there's no reason to close your scalp. If X% < Y%, then you will close your scalp with a value bet.


Of course this assumes that your detection of value is actually somewhat sensible.

text: Then you know that you're going to get a +EV bet and a -EV bet and that the +EV one will out-weigh the -EV so overall you'll be matching +EV bets. We're all making individual -EV bets all the time because we can't avoid it, that's fine. It's knowingly matching -EV bets that's the problem and when you 'trade out' that's what you're doing. EDIT: You might also be getting 2 +EV bets because the 0EV price was mid-spread.

Sure i'd be giving away potentially, but in a way you're paying for the convenience of not having to figure out whether you are taking value or not.

text: Just one other thing: It is sometimes said that 'trading out' allows larger stakes and thus leverages a smaller bank. This is obviously nonsense as the profit of a 'closed' position on a big bet is the same as the profit of a smaller bet that wasn't 'closed' - except that you've lost a bit by taking a -EV exit bet.

text: I'm going to expand on why 'closing' bets are inherently loss making because it illustrates a fundamental feature of profitable betting that is terribly important but isn't generally well understood and it might help some people.

elements.text: I'm going to expand on why 'closing' bets are inherently loss making because it illustrates a fundamental feature of profitable betting that is terribly important but isn't generally well understood and it might help some people.

text: This is going to be a super simple explanation so please bear with me if some of it seems too obvious for words. It is predicated on a basic understanding of value betting. I will use the abbreviations +EV and -EV for positive expected value and negative expected value respectively.

elements.text: This is going to be a super simple explanation so please bear with me if some of it seems too obvious for words. It is predicated on a basic understanding of value betting. I will use the abbreviations +EV and -EV for positive expected value and negative expected value respectively.

text: Here goes:

elements.text: Here goes:

text: At any time you can submit a bet at any odds you want and it may or may not match. If you submit a bet that is more favourable to you then it is less likely to match than one which is less favourable to you. An extreme example spells this out: If a selection is generally matching at 2 and you submit a back bet at 1000 (which would almost certainly be a +EV bet) then it's very unlikely to match. On the other hand if you submit a back bet at 1.01 it will almost certainly match and it will almost certainly be -EV. The same effect exists between 2.01 and 1.99, it's less marked but it's the same effect. So far so obvious right? Let's extend the example by assuming that a bet at 2 would have zero expected value, which would be the default assumption in an efficient market. If you submitted a back bet at 2 it would be very likely to match, but it wouldn't be certain.

elements.text: At any time you can submit a bet at any odds you want and it may or may not match. If you submit a bet that is more favourable to you then it is less likely to match than one which is less favourable to you. An extreme example spells this out: If a selection is generally matching at 2 and you submit a back bet at 1000 (which would almost certainly be a +EV bet) then it's very unlikely to match. On the other hand if you submit a back bet at 1.01 it will almost certainly match and it will almost certainly be -EV. The same effect exists between 2.01 and 1.99, it's less marked but it's the same effect. So far so obvious right? Let's extend the example by assuming that a bet at 2 would have zero expected value, which would be the default assumption in an efficient market. If you submitted a back bet at 2 it would be very likely to match, but it wouldn't be certain.

text: Now we can take the above and transform it into a line plotted on a graph. The graph would show how likely a bet was to match (from 0 to 1) on the Y axis plotted against its expected value (from -1 to +1) on the X axis.

elements.text: Now we can take the above and transform it into a line plotted on a graph. The graph would show how likely a bet was to match (from 0 to 1) on the Y axis plotted against its expected value (from -1 to +1) on the X axis.

text: Our example gives us 3 points that we can put on the graph to help us plot the line. A bet with a very negative EV (that's your back bet at 1.01) would be virtually certain to match, so you have a point on your graph at the top left hand corner. A bet with a very positive EV (your back at 1000) would be extraordinarily unlikely to match – so that's a point in the bottom right corner. Your 0EV bet (backing at 2) goes in the middle of the X axis, and it was likely but not certain to match so it's almost at the top of the Y. Now that you've got three points you can guess the shape of the curve that connects them, for these purposes it doesn't matter exactly what shape you draw, all that matters is that you can see that the right hand half of the line (where the +EV bets are) slopes down from a probability a little bit below 1 (slightly less than certain) to almost 0 (virtually impossible).

elements.text: Our example gives us 3 points that we can put on the graph to help us plot the line. A bet with a very negative EV (that's your back bet at 1.01) would be virtually certain to match, so you have a point on your graph at the top left hand corner. A bet with a very positive EV (your back at 1000) would be extraordinarily unlikely to match – so that's a point in the bottom right corner. Your 0EV bet (backing at 2) goes in the middle of the X axis, and it was likely but not certain to match so it's almost at the top of the Y. Now that you've got three points you can guess the shape of the curve that connects them, for these purposes it doesn't matter exactly what shape you draw, all that matters is that you can see that the right hand half of the line (where the +EV bets are) slopes down from a probability a little bit below 1 (slightly less than certain) to almost 0 (virtually impossible).

text: The graph equips you to either see how likely a bet is to match depending on its EV OR to look at it the other way round and say something like _“if I want 50% of my bets to match what amount of value should I request.”_

elements.text: The graph equips you to either see how likely a bet is to match depending on its EV OR to look at it the other way round and say something like
“if I want 50% of my bets to match what amount of value should I request.”

text: OK but what's the relevance to 'closing' positions right? Here it is: When you open a position you can put a bet into the market at any value you want, so naturally you're going to ask for a +EV bet and it might match or it might not. If it matches that's great – you've got a nice +EV bet and if it doesn't match it doesn't matter, you neither win nor lose so who cares. Hooray, you're a +EV gambler, order that Porsche.

elements.text: OK but what's the relevance to 'closing' positions right? Here it is: When you open a position you can put a bet into the market at any value you want, so naturally you're going to ask for a +EV bet and it might match or it might not. If it matches that's great – you've got a nice +EV bet and if it doesn't match it doesn't matter, you neither win nor lose so who cares. Hooray, you're a +EV gambler, order that Porsche.

text: But wait.... what's that you say? You decided in advance to 'close' your position? Well that's a different bet, because that bet MUST match, you're just not willing to contemplate it not matching. Let's look at our graph again then, but this time read it the other way... where are the bets that are certain to match? Oh.... they're all on the -EV side. Q.E.D. innit blood.

elements.text: But wait.... what's that you say? You decided in advance to 'close' your position? Well that's a different bet, because that bet MUST match, you're just not willing to contemplate it not matching. Let's look at our graph again then, but this time read it the other way... where are the bets that are certain to match? Oh.... they're all on the -EV side. Q.E.D. innit blood.

text: One last time in case anyone's left: Your opening bet can be +EV because you're happy with the idea that it might not match, but your closing bet must be -EV because your determination to make it match makes it so.

elements.text: One last time in case anyone's left: Your opening bet can be +EV because you're happy with the idea that it might not match, but your closing bet must be -EV because your determination to make it match makes it so.

text: More widely: A thorough understanding of the relationship between the EV of a bet and its probability of matching is about the best thing you can have.

elements.text: More widely: A thorough understanding of the relationship between the EV of a bet and its probability of matching is about the best thing you can have.

text:
That was nicely articulated, you've made it very easily to visualise there, much appreciated...although I do have one question if I may...

If you have 2 strategies for value betting, 1 only ever backs, 1 only ever lays (but independent) and execution is only if value is there (i.e. you never close out simply because you have a position), are you eroding value there? I'm sort of confusing myself thinking 1 has to be -EV, but also if the price moves, could they not both be +EV at the point of execution?

text:
Suppose you back at 2.01, and your fair value estimate is 1.5.

Your commission rate is 2%.

Your fair value estimate changes to 2.0.

Would you put in a limit order to exit your position at 2.0? Or would you let the bet ride?

elements.text:
Suppose you back at 2.01, and your fair value estimate is 1.5.

Your commission rate is 2%.

Your fair value estimate changes to 2.0.

Would you put in a limit order to exit your position at 2.0? Or would you let the bet ride?

text: No - if all your bets are triggered by signals of value you're all good.

text: You'd be placing your bets at different times, wouldn't you? Things change in time so odds that are +EV at one time can become -EV if struck at a different time. You can only evaluate your bets according to the moment they were placed, nothing else would make sense.

elements.text: You'd be placing your bets at different times, wouldn't you? Things change in time so odds that are +EV at one time can become -EV if struck at a different time. You can only evaluate your bets according to the moment they were placed, nothing else would make sense.

text: So it can make complete sense to back something at 2 and later lay it at 4, both bets can be +EV.

elements.text: So it can make complete sense to back something at 2 and later lay it at 4, both bets can be +EV.

text: yes different times, completely independently, but I'm thinking of the hypothetical bot A places a bet with 30 seconds to go, backing @ 5, bot B lays @ 3 with 5 seconds to go

text: If a selection is 0EV at 1.5 there would be no rational reason to lay it at 2.

text: Here's where this problem comes from: A bunch of software vendors have a vested interest in getting people to 'trade' on their platforms, and Betfair are into that too. And the vendors and betfair want to target people who wouldn't be caught dead spunking a hundred quid on backing a dog because that's gambling and gambling is for mugs. So they make up a load of shit about how placing bets somehow isn't betting even though you're doing it on a site called BETfair and they say that the maths of gambling (which is really pretty simple) doesn't apply because  somehow it's not gambling even though it's regulated by the gambling commission who's only job is to regulate gambling (there is no 'trading commission') . Then for years on end they pump out their crap to people who want to hear it and those people repeat it and other people somehow start to think it's true even though when you step back from it it's obviously just horse shit and anyone who can do basic maths (like adding and subtracting) can prove it with a pencil. It honestly makes me furious.

It honestly makes me furious.

text: Sorry I mis-read your question - Probabilities do change in time so it's rational to place different bets at different times. In the scenario you mention it was first rational to place your initial back bet at 2.01 (or whatever better than 1.5) and later it might be rational to place a lay bet anywhere better than 2 because the situation has changed, but those two bets have no relationship to each other, they are two separate +EV bets. The fact that they're both in your account rather than being struck by two different people is of no significance.

elements.text: Sorry I mis-read your question - Probabilities do change in time so it's rational to place different bets at different times. In the scenario you mention it was first rational to place your initial back bet at 2.01 (or whatever better than 1.5) and later it might be rational to place a lay bet anywhere better than 2 because the situation has changed, but those two bets have no relationship to each other, they are two separate +EV bets. The fact that they're both in your account rather than being struck by two different people is of no significance.

text: <@U01B8031PM1> - I find Starlizard a "dubious" proposition, not because I don't think they make money, but for one very good reason: 1) None of the other really big players bet anything other than their own money - why dilute your winnings when you have more than enough to do anything?

text: On the "hedging issue. One thing I have learnt is that if you have a successful model, you never hedge (learnt that by working for big clients). Why minimise profits if the model is successful overall?

elements.text: On the "hedging issue. One thing I have learnt is that if you have a successful model, you never hedge (learnt that by working for big clients). Why minimise profits if the model is successful overall?

text: Tony Bloom has certainly made a lot of money somehow but I agree that Starlizard is a strange outfit and there may be something about it that we don't know.

text: The other big players run almost clandestine operations - you can't see anything they do "behind the scenes"

text: <@U016535QCJ2> "Why minimise profits if the model is successful overall?" - this is a key point though. How many recreational users on Betfair have the skills to gather a dataset and generate a statistical model and then validate it to the extent that you are confident enough in your estimates that you would "know" the size of your edge? It might even be argued that to get a REALLY successful model you need access to bespoke data that hardly anyone else has access to. Yes, with a good model you can "know" how +EV a particular bet is going to be and even optimise profit with Kelly staking, but the key is knowing what the true 0EV price actually is (or at least a tight confidence interval around it). Understanding the concept of value IS just basic probability but that may well be beyond a lot of users of the exchanges - but almost everyone would see the merits of piling onto a steamer and (hoping) that they can get off before it reverses so it is completely understandable why many people hedge. I am currently hedging +EV positions and I acknowledge that what I am doing is foolish but I do so purely to help counter the variance. As <@UGV299K6H> says, this can be alleviated by appropriate staking and I am working to correct this element of my strategy and long term I will stop doing so (assuming the edge disappears).
